term_definitions.items: *The local measurement of arterial blood pressure which is a surrogate for arterial. pressure in the systemic circulation. Most commonly, use of the term 'blood pressure' refers to measurement of brachial artery pressure in the upper arm.(en)
*Peak systemic arterial blood pressure - measured in systolic or contraction phase of the heart cycle.(en)
*Minimum systemic arterial blood pressure - measured in the diastolic or relaxation phase of the heart cycle.(en)
*The position of the subject at the time of measurement.(en)
*Perloff D, Grim C, Flack J, Frohlich ED, Hill M, McDonald M, Morgenstern BZ. Human blood pressure determination by sphygmomanometry. Circulation 1993;88;2460-2470. (en)
*The size of the cuff used for blood pressure measurement. (en)
*Common body sites where blood pressure is recorded.(en)
*A cuff used for an adult thigh - bladder approx 20cm x 42cm.(en)
*A cuff for adults with larger arms - bladder approx 16cm x 38cm.(en)
*A cuff that is standard for an adult - bladder approx 13cm x 30cm.(en)
*Standing at the time of blood pressure measurement.(en)
*Sitting (for example on bed or chair) at the time of blood pressure measurement.(en)
*Reclining at the time of blood pressure measurement.(en)
*Lying flat at the time of blood pressure measurement.(en)
*The craniocaudal tilt of the surface on which the person is lying at the time of measurement.(en)
*The average arterial pressure that occurs over the entire course of the heart contraction and relaxation cycle.(en)
*The difference between the systolic and diastolic pressure.(en)
*A cuff used for a small adult - bladder approx 10cm x 24cm.(en)
*A cuff that is appropriate for a child or adult with a thin arm - bladder approx 8cm x 21cm.(en)
*Record which Korotkoff sound is used for determining diastolic pressure using auscultative method.(en)
*The fourth Korotkoff sound is identified as an abrupt muffling of sounds.(en)
*The fifth Korotkoff sound is identified by absence of sounds as the cuff pressure drops below the diastolic blood pressure.(en)
*Lying flat with some lateral tilt, usually angled towards the left side. Commonly required in the last trimester of pregnancy to relieve aortocaval compression.(en)
*A cuff used for infants - bladder approx 5cm x 15cm.(en)
*A cuff used for a neonate, assuming cuff is the appropriate size for maturity and birthweight of the neonate.(en)
*Details about sphygmomanometer or other device used to measure the blood pressure.(en)
*Details about physical activity undertaken at the time of blood pressure.measurement.(en)
*A finger of the subject. Identification of the finger can be recorded in 'Specific Location' data element, if required.(en)

*Body location where blood pressure is measured. Use 'Location of measurement' to select from common sites. Use 'Specific location' to record more specific details or a site that is not in the common set or to refer to an external terminology.(en)
*Specific details about the body site where blood pressure is recorded.(en)
*Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using a stethoscope and Korotkoff sounds.(en)
*Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using palpation (usually of the brachial or radial arteries).(en)
*Formula used to calculate the MAP (if recorded in data).(en)
*Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using a blood pressure machine.(en)
*Method of measuring blood pressure internally ie involving penetration of the skin and measuring inside blood vessels.(en)
*Estimate of the average blood pressure over a 24 hour period.(en)
*Sleep status - supports interpretation of 24 hour ambulatory blood pressure records. (en)
*Subject is in the natural state of bodily rest.(en)
*A toe of the subject. Identification of the toe can be recorded in 'Specific Location' data element, if required.(en)

*Comment on and record other incidental factors that may be contributing to the blood pressure measurement. For example, level of anxiety or 'white coat syndrome'; pain or fever; changes in atmospheric pressure etc.(en)
*Invasive measurement via transducer access line within an artery. Location of the transducer can be recorded in 'Specific Location' data element, if required.(en)
*The method used to determine the result of the test.(en)
*The result was derived from a visual estimate of a test strip.(en)
*The result was estimated automatically by machine from a test strip.(en)
*A laboratory analyser was used to determine the result.(en)
Podatki o laboratoriju, ki je odgovoren za izvajanje testa
Dodatni rezultati testa kot dodatek začasnim rezultatom
Popravljeni rezltati testa, ki postavijo vse prejšnje rezultate v status ne veljavnosti
*The date and time related to the results status is useful for version control and cumulative results for the report.(en)
Razmerje hemoglobina v krvi, ki je "glycolysed"
Podatki o laboratoriju, ki je odgovoren za izvajanje testa
Dodatni rezultati testa kot dodatek začasnim rezultatom
Popravljeni rezltati testa, ki postavijo vse prejšnje rezultate v status ne veljavnosti
*The date and time related to the results status is useful for version control and cumulative results for the report.(en)
Acts as a container for a set of archetype which represent a single data-capture screen.
Generic encounter or progress note composition

items.items: Generic encounter or progress note composition
Generic encounter or progress note composition
Acts as a container for a set of archetype which represent a single date-capture screen.
Acts as a container for a set of archetype which represent a single data-capture screen.

The local measurement of arterial blood pressure which is a surrogate for arterial. pressure in the systemic circulation. Most commonly, use of the term 'blood pressure' refers to measurement of brachial artery pressure in the upper arm.
Peak systemic arterial blood pressure - measured in systolic or contraction phase of the heart cycle.
Minimum systemic arterial blood pressure - measured in the diastolic or relaxation phase of the heart cycle.
The position of the subject at the time of measurement.
Perloff D, Grim C, Flack J, Frohlich ED, Hill M, McDonald M, Morgenstern BZ. Human blood pressure determination by sphygmomanometry. Circulation 1993;88;2460-2470.
The size of the cuff used for blood pressure measurement.
Common body sites where blood pressure is recorded.
A cuff used for an adult thigh - bladder approx 20cm x 42cm.
A cuff for adults with larger arms - bladder approx 16cm x 38cm.
A cuff that is standard for an adult - bladder approx 13cm x 30cm.
The right arm of the person.
The left arm of the person.
The right thigh of the person.
The left thigh of the person.
Standing at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Sitting (for example on bed or chair) at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Reclining at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Lying flat at the time of blood pressure measurement.
The craniocaudal tilt of the surface on which the person is lying at the time of measurement.
The average arterial pressure that occurs over the entire course of the heart contraction and relaxation cycle.
The difference between the systolic and diastolic pressure.
A cuff used for a small adult - bladder approx 10cm x 24cm.
A cuff that is appropriate for a child or adult with a thin arm - bladder approx 8cm x 21cm.
Record which Korotkoff sound is used for determining diastolic pressure using auscultative method.
The fourth Korotkoff sound is identified as an abrupt muffling of sounds.
The fifth Korotkoff sound is identified by absence of sounds as the cuff pressure drops below the diastolic blood pressure.
Lying flat with some lateral tilt, usually angled towards the left side. Commonly required in the last trimester of pregnancy to relieve aortocaval compression.
A cuff used for infants - bladder approx 5cm x 15cm.
A cuff used for a neonate, assuming cuff is the appropriate size for maturity and birthweight of the neonate.
The right wrist of the subject.
The left wrist of the subject.
Details about sphygmomanometer or other device used to measure the blood pressure.
The right ankle of the subject.
Details about physical activity undertaken at the time of blood pressure.measurement.
The left ankle of the subject.
A finger of the subject. Identification of the finger can be recorded in 'Specific Location' data element, if required.

Body location where blood pressure is measured. Use 'Location of measurement' to select from common sites. Use 'Specific location' to record more specific details or a site that is not in the common set or to refer to an external terminology.
Specific details about the body site where blood pressure is recorded.
Method of measurement of blood pressure.
Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using a stethoscope and Korotkoff sounds.
Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using palpation (usually of the brachial or radial arteries).
Formula used to calculate the MAP (if recorded in data).
Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using a blood pressure machine.
Method of measuring blood pressure internally ie involving penetration of the skin and measuring inside blood vessels.
Estimate of the average blood pressure over a 24 hour period.
Sleep status - supports interpretation of 24 hour ambulatory blood pressure records.
Subject is in the natural state of bodily rest.
A toe of the subject. Identification of the toe can be recorded in 'Specific Location' data element, if required.

Comment on and record other incidental factors that may be contributing to the blood pressure measurement. For example, level of anxiety or 'white coat syndrome'; pain or fever; changes in atmospheric pressure etc.
Invasive measurement via transducer access line within an artery. Location of the transducer can be recorded in 'Specific Location' data element, if required.

*The difference between the systolic and diastolic pressure.(en)
*A cuff used for a small adult - bladder approx 10cm x 24cm.(en)
*A cuff that is appropriate for a child or adult with a thin arm - bladder approx 8cm x 21cm.(en)

*The fourth Korotkoff sound is identified as an abrupt muffling of sounds.(en)
*The fifth Korotkoff sound is identified by absence of sounds as the cuff pressure drops below the diastolic blood pressure.(en)
*Lying flat with some lateral tilt, usually angled towards the left side. Commonly required in the last trimester of pregnancy to relieve aortocaval compression.(en)
*A cuff used for infants - bladder approx 5cm x 15cm.(en)
*A cuff used for a neonate, assuming cuff is the appropriate size for maturity and birthweight of the neonate.(en)

*Details about physical activity undertaken at the time of blood pressure.measurement.(en)

*Body location where blood pressure is measured. Use 'Location of measurement' to select from common sites. Use 'Specific location' to record more specific details or a site that is not in the common set or to refer to an external terminology.(en)
*Specific details about the body site where blood pressure is recorded.(en)
*Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using a stethoscope and Korotkoff sounds.(en)
*Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using palpation (usually of the brachial or radial arteries).(en)
*Formula used to calculate the MAP (if recorded in data).(en)
*Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using a blood pressure machine.(en)
*Method of measuring blood pressure internally ie involving penetration of the skin and measuring inside blood vessels.(en)
*Estimate of the average blood pressure over a 24 hour period.(en)

*Subject is in the natural state of bodily rest.(en)

*Invasive measurement via transducer access line within an artery. Location of the transducer can be recorded in 'Specific Location' data element, if required.(en)
The route of administration of the glucose challenge.
The sample was taken prior to the challenge.
The sample was taken after the challenge.
The route of administration of the insulin.
The method used to determine the result of the test.
The result was derived from a visual estimate of a test strip.
The result was estimated automatically by machine from a test strip.
A laboratory analyser was used to determine the result.
Description of when the patient has eaten.
The timing of the specimen in relation to the intake.
Information about a glucose challenge if relevant.
The relationship of the sample to the challenge.
The concentration of glucose in the blood.

Specific identifier for this lab test. e.g. Full blood count , blood glucose, urine microbiology. May equate to the result name for a single value result. Commonly a coded term e.g from LOINC or SNOMED-CT.
Representations of the whole test in mutlimedia e.g image, audio, video.
Demographic details of the laboratory with responsibility for the test. Details of secondary laboratories may also be included.
This is an initial or interim result - further updates are anticipated.
This is the final result. No further alterations are anticipated.
This is a supplementary result ehich should be appended to a previous result.
This is a correction which should completely replace any previous results.
An overall interpretative comment on this test.
The local ID assigned to the order by the order requester. Equivalent to the Placer Order Identifier.
The local ID assigned to the test order by the order filler, usually by the (LIS) Laboratory Information System. Equivalent to the DICOM Accession Number and the Filler Order Identifier.
Details of the specimen being reported where all individual results are derived from the same specimen.
The identifier given to the laboratory test result of a pathology investigation.
The status of the lab test as a whole.
The test was aborted and never completed.
The date and time related to the results status is useful for version control and cumulative results for the report.
The date and/or time that the result was issued for the recorded ‘test status’.
The type of high-level diagnostic service e.g. biochemistry, haematology.
Concentration of blood glucose in the sample.
Slot to allow an annotation to be added to a particular test result at run-time.
Details of the clinician or organisation requesting the laboratory test.
*The method used to determine the result of the test.(en)
*The result was derived from a visual estimate of a test strip.(en)
*The result was estimated automatically by machine from a test strip.(en)
*A laboratory analyser was used to determine the result.(en)
Podatki o laboratoriju, ki je odgovoren za izvajanje testa
Dodatni rezultati testa kot dodatek začasnim rezultatom
Popravljeni rezltati testa, ki postavijo vse prejšnje rezultate v status ne veljavnosti
*The date and time related to the results status is useful for version control and cumulative results for the report.(en)

To record the result of a laboratory test which may be used to record a single valued test but will often be specialised or templated to represent multiple value or 'panel' tests. This archetype also acts as the parent for specialisations appropriate for more specific laboratory tests microbiology, histopathology.
The proportion of haemaglobin in the blood that is glycosylated.

Specific identifier for this lab test. e.g. Full blood count , blood glucose, urine microbiology. May equate to the result name for a single value result. Commonly a coded term e.g from LOINC or SNOMED-CT.
Representations of the whole test in mutlimedia e.g image, audio, video.
Demographic details of the laboratory with responsibility for the test. Details of secondary laboratories may also be included.
This is an initial or interim result - further updates are anticipated
This is the final result. No further alterations are anticipated
This is a supplememtary result in addition to the Interim result
This is a Correction which should replace any previous results
An overall interpretative comment on this test.
The local ID assigned to the order by the order requester. Equivalent to the Placer Order Identifier.
The local ID assigned to the test order by the order filler, usually by the (LIS) Laboratory Information System. Equivalent to the DICOM Accession Number and the Filler Order Identifier.
Details of the specimen being reported where all individual results are derived from the same specimen
The identifier given to the laboratory test result of a pathology investigation.
The status of the lab test as a whole.
The date and time related to the results status is useful for version control and cumulative results for the report.
The date and/or time that the result was issued for the recorded ‘test status’.
The type of high-level diagnostic service e.g. biochemistry, haematology.
Slot to allow an annotation to be added to a particular test result at run-time.
Details of the clinician or organisation requesting the laboratory test.
